entry.title: Big Data - Map Reduce
entry.content:
Large Scale Computing for Data Mining

  • Process a lot of data to produce other data
  • Requirements
    • CPU, Memory, HDD, …
    • Multiple machine

Cluster Architecture

Fat-tree Architecture

  • Mining big data requires large-scale computing whose key component is parallel programming

Basic Operation: MapReduce

  • Created by Google (Jeffry Dean and Sanjay Chemawat) in 2004
  • Inspired from LISP
    • Map
      • Applies the given function to each element of the set
      • (map ‘length’(() (a) (a b) (a b c)) => (0 1 2 3)
    • Reduce
      • (reduce #’+’(1 2 3 4 5)) => 15

MapReduce is also Framework

  • Apache Hadoop MapReduce, Amazon Elastic MapReduce
  • Framework for parallel computing
    • Parallelization
    • Data distribution
    • Load balancing
    • Fault tolerance
  • Programmers get simple API
  • Allows one to process hug amount of data on thousands of processors

MapReduce as Programming Model

  • Sample problem
    • Find top 10URLs by access frequency by analyzing log files from web server(s)
  • The problem can be converted as WordCount
    • Counting words in a huge text document

WordCount

  • Assume that a file is too large for memory, but all <word, count> pairs fit in memory
    1. load a part of the file - Map
    2. count word - Map
    3. merge - Reduce
  • Each sub-task can be run in parallel
    • Reduce not only the resource usage, but execution time

Generalize Formally

  • Input: a set of key-value pairs
  • 2 methods:
    • Map(k, v) -> <k’, v’>*
    • Reduce( k’, <v’>* ) -> <k’, v’’>*

MapReduce: A Logical Diagram

MapReduce: Environment

MapReduce environment takes care of the following:

  • Partitioning the input data
  • Scheduling the program’s execution across a set of machines
  • Performing the group by key step
  • Handling machine failures
  • Managing required inter-machine communication

MapReduce: A Physical Diagram

Reference

  • Mining of Massive Datasets by Jure Leskovec, Anand Rajaraman, Jeff Ullman
  • Introduction to Big Data Lecture by Daejin Choi in Incheon National University

entry.title: Spring Boot - Injecting Data using Implemented Service

link.title: Spring Boot - Injecting Data using Implemented Service

entry.content:
I needed to inject some data that are in .csv format when starting Spring Boot using the service. I know that one of the options that I had was CommandLineRunner. However, I wanted to make my code clean.

CommandLineRunner Example

@EnableJpaAuditing
@SpringBootApplication
public class SpringApplication {
    
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SpringApplication.run(SpringApplication.class, args);
    }
    
    @Bean
    CommandLineRunner runner(ExampleService service) {
        return args -> {
            service.save("example");
        }
    }
}

I found another choice which was using ApplicationRunner. I chose this method because I was able to separate the specific codes that I need for inserting data. Also, I personally think that this way of structuring code is cleaner.

ApplicationRunner Example

@Component
@RequiredArgsConstructor
public class InitialDataInsert implements ApplicationRunner {
    
    private final ExampleService service;
    
    public void insertData() {
        service.save("example");
    }
    
    @Override
    public void run(ApplicationArguments args) throw Exception {
        insertData();
    }
}

Reference

  • Application Runner in Spring Document

entry.title: Unreal Engine - Level Editor
entry.content:
Basic Terms

  • Unreal Editor: Development environment for Unreal engine.
  • Level Editor: An interface used for the design and construction of game levels and environments.
  • Level: Made up of a collection of static meshes, volumes, lights, blueprints, and more all working together to bring the desired experience to a player.
  • Asset: A piece of content for an Unreal project and can be thought of as a UObject serialized to a file.
  • Actor: Object in level such as a camera, static mesh, or player start location.

Default Interface

Coordinates

The coordinates follow left hand rule as you may have learned in high school physics class.

  • thumb: Points upward and represents the z-coordinate.
  • index finger: Points towards and represents the y-coordinate.
  • middle finger: Points to the right and represents the x-coordinate.

Camera control in view port

Move the camera around using these keys:

  • right click + w/s: move forward/backward
  • right click + a/d: move left/right
  • right click + q/e: move upward/downward

  • right click + z/c: zoom out/in

  • left click + drag: rotate left/right, move forward/backward horizontally
  • right click + drag: rotate left/right/upwards/downwards

  • wheel click + drag: move left/right horizontally, move upwards/downwards in perpendicular

  • left click + option/alt + drag: move around centering a pivot
  • right click + option/alt + drag: move towards/away from a pivot

  • wheel click + option/alt + drag: move left/right horizontally and forward/backward in perpendicular

  • select an object + f: focus the object

entry.title: Big Data - Data Mining Research
entry.content:
Introduction to Data Mining

What is Data Mining(DM)?

  • data mining: Extraction of interesting(non-trivial, implicit, previously unknown and potentially useful) pattern or knowledge from huge amount of data.
    • aka. Knowledge Extraction, Data Analysis, Data Science Information Harvesting, Business Intelligence, Predictive Analysis, etc.

KDD Process

Key Components in Data Mining

  • Data & Datatype
    • Database Data (extended-relational, object-oriented, heterogeneous, legacy), Data Warehouse, Transactional Data, Stream, Spatio-temporal, Time-series, Sequence, Text and Web, Multi-media, Graphs & Social and Information Networks
  • Data Mining Functions
    • Characterization, Discrimination, Association, Classification, Clustering, Trend/Deviation, Outlier Analysis, etc.
    • Descriptive vs Predictive Data Mining
    • Multiple/Integrated Functions and Mining at Multiple Levels
  • Techniques Utilized
    • Data-intensive, Machine Learning, Statistics, Pattern Recognition, Visualization, High-performance, etc.
  • Applications Adapted
    • Retail, Telecommunication, Banking, Fraud Analysis, Bio-data Mining, Stock Market Analysis, Health Care, etc.

DM Component: Data & Datatype

  • Database-oriented datasets and applications
    • Relational database, data warehouse, transactional database
  • Advanced Datasets and advanced applications
    • Data streams and sensor data
    • Time-series data, temporal data, sequence data (including bio-sequences)
    • Structure data, graphs, social networks and multi-linked data
    • Spatial data and spatio-temporal data
    • Multimedia database
    • Text databases
    • The World-Wide Web
  • Generalization
    • Multidimensional concept description: Characterization and discrimination
  • Association and Correlation Analysis
    • Frequent patterns or frequent item sets
    • How to mine such patterns and rules efficiently in large datasets?
    • How to use such pattern for classification, clustering, and other applications?
  • Classification
    • Construct models based on some training examples
    • Describe and distinguish classes or concepts for future prediction
      • e.g. Classify countries based on climate, or classify cars based on gas mileage
    • Predict some unknown class labels
  • Cluster Analysis
    • Unsupervised learning
    • Group data to form new categories
    • Principle: Maximizing intra-class similarity & minimizing inter-class similarity
  • Outlier Analysis
    • Outlier: A data object that does not comply with the general behavior of the data
    • Noise or exception
    • Useful in fraud detection, rare events analysis

DM Component: Techniques to be used

DM Component: Applications adapted

  • Web Analysis
    • e.g. from web page classification, clustering to PageRank algorithms
  • Collaborative analysis & recommender system
  • Basket data analysis to targeted marketing
  • Biological and medical data analysis: classification, cluster analysis, biological sequence analysis, biological sequence analysis, biological network analysis
  • Social networks
  • Journalism
  • Culture & Society

Diverse Issues in DM

  • Mining Methodology
    • Mining various and new kinds of knowledge
    • Mining knowledge in multidimensional space
    • Boosting the power of discovery in a networked environment
    • Handling noise, uncertainty, and incompleteness of data
    • Pattern evaluation and pattern- or constraint-guided mining
  • User Interaction
    • Interactive mining
    • Incorporation of background knowledge
    • Presentation and visualization of data mining results
  • Efficiency and Scalability
    • Efficiency and scalability of data mining algorithms
    • Parallel, distributed, stream, and incremental mining methods
    • Diversity of data types
  • Handling complex types of data
    • Mining dynamic, networked, and global data repositories
  • Data mining and society
    • Social impacts of data mining
    • Privacy-preserving data mining

Practical Tips for Starting Data Mining

Think the process first!

  • What is the exact problem?
  • What data do we need? Is the data available?
  • How can we represent the data?
  • What DM functions/techniques will you use?

1️⃣ step: Problem Definition

  • Define the problem as a scientific form
    • From a rough, uncertain, and undetailed problem to a clear and specific problem
  • Require domain knowledge as well as scientific problem-solving capability

2️⃣ step: Data Collection

  • Collecting data via
    • e.g. devices collection, web crawling, …

3️⃣ step: Data Representation

  • Transforming a high-dimensional raw data into problem-relevant data
  • Quantifying data with various techniques
    • Based on information theory, algorithm, and domain knowledge

Applying DM Functions/Techniques

  • Applying appropriate DM techniques
    • e.g. machine learning, statistical analysis, time-series analysis
    • multiple techniques can be applied together
  • Quantitative vs Qualitative -> Complementary

✅ Summary

Tip ❗️

One cycle is “ALWAYS” not enough! You need to go many (= hundreds or even thousands) cycles to conclude a claim.

Reference

  • Mining of Massive Datasets by Jure Leskovec, Anand Rajaraman, Jeff Ullman
  • Introduction to Big Data Lecture by Daejin Choi in Incheon National University

entry.title: Computer Network - The Network Edge
entry.content:
Hosts are divided into two categories: clients and server

  • clients: desktop, laptops, smartphones, and so on.
  • servers: powerful machines that store and distribute Web pages, stream videos, relay email, and so on.
  • data centers: stores most of the servers from which we receive search results, email, Web pages, videos, and so on.

1️⃣ Access Networks

  • edge router: the network that physically connects an end system to the first router.

Home Access: DLS, Cable, FTTH, and 5G Fixed Wireless

Two most prevalent types of broadband residential access today: digital subscriber line(DLS) and cable

  • digital subscriber line(DSL): uses the existing telephone line exchange data with a digital subscriber line access multiplexer(DLAM)

The residential telephone line carries both data and traditional telephone signals

  • A high-speed downstream channel: 50 kHz ~ 1 MHz
  • A medium-speed upstream channel: 4 kHz ~ 50 kHz
  • An ordinary two-way telephone channel: 0 ~ 4 kHz

  • cable Internet access: makes use of the television company’s existing cable television infrastructure.

The downstream channel and upstream channel all depends on how many users are active, because users in the same network share a single channel.

  • fiber to the home(FTTH): an up-and-coming technology that provides even higher speed.
    • FTTH provide an optical fiber path from the CO directly to the home and allow gigabits per second range.

There are two competing optical-distribution network architectures: active optical networks(AONs) and passive optical networks(PONs)

  • active optical networks(AON): switched Ethernet.
  • passive optical networks(PONs): Figure 1.7 shows FTTH using PON distribution architecture.
    • Each home has optical network terminator(ONT)
    • The ONTs are connected by dedicated optical fiber to a neighborhood splitter and combines them into a single shared optical fiber

  • 5G fixed wireless: uses beam-forming technology and send data wirelessly from a provider’s base station to the a modem at home.

Access in the Enterprise (and the Home): Ethernet and WiFi

  • Ethernet: twisted-pair copper wire to connect to an Ethernet switch.
  • WiFi: wireless LAN access based on IEEE 802.11 technology.
    • 802.11 today provides a shared transmission rate of up to < 100 Mbps.

2️⃣ Physical Media

  • physical medium: allows data to be sent by propagating electromagnetic waves or optical pulses across.
  • There are two types of physical media: guided media and unguided media
    • guided media: the waves are guided along a solid medium such as a fiber-optic cable, a twisted-pair copper wire, or a coaxial cable
    • unguided media: the waves propagate in the atmosphere and in outer space such as in a wireless LAN or digital satellite channel.

Twisted-Pair Copper Wire

Twisted-pair copper wire is the least expensive and most commonly used guided transmission medium.

  • Unshielded twisted pair(UTP): commonly used for computer networks within a building, LANs for instance.
    • Range 10 Mbps - 10 Gbps, depending on the thickness of the wire and the distance between the transmitter and receiver.

Coaxial Cable

Coaxial cable is commonly used for television systems, which has been coupled with cable modems to provide Internet access.

  • shared medium: more than one receiver are hooked up to the transmitter.
    • In this case, transmitter shifts the digital signal to a specific frequency band which different end systems can receive.

Fiber Optics

Optics fiber is thin and flexible medium that conduct pulses of light, with each pulse representing a bit. It also is the prevalent in the backbone of the Internet, but it is expensive. Its speed range 51.8 Mbps to 39.8 Gbps.

Terrestrial Radio Channels

Terrestrial radio channels carry signals in the electromagnetic spectrum. They do not require physical wire to be installed.

Satellite Radio Channels

Satellite links two or more Earth-based microwave transmitter/receiver.

  • geostationary satellites: permanently remains above the same spot on Earth. It is often used in areas without access to DLS or cable-based Internet access, but have substantial signal propagation delay of 280 ms.
  • low-earth orbiting(LEO): placed much closer to Earth compared to geostationary satellites and do not remain permanently above one spot on Earth. It could be the technology for Internet access in the future.

Reference

  • Computer Networking 8th: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross
  • Computer Network Lecture by Seungsik Choi in Incheon National University

entry.title: Computer Network - What is the Internet

link.title: Computer Network - What is the Internet

entry.content:
1️⃣ A Nuts-and-Bolts Description

  • The Internet: A computer network that interconnects billions of computing devices.
    • Today, approximately half of the world’s population are active mobile Internet users.
    • By 2025, users in the Internet is expected to increase upto 75%.
  • Hosts or End system: Devices that have Internet connection.

  • Communication links and Packet switches: Network that connects end systems together.
  • Transmission rate: Rate that different links can transmit data, measured in bits/seconds.
  • Packets: The resulting packages of information that are sent through the network to the destination end system, where they are reassembled into the original data.
  • Routers and Link-layer switches: Two most prominent types of packet switches. They forward packets toward their ultimate destinations.
  • Route or Path: The sequence of communication links and packet switches traverse.
  • Internet Service Providers(ISPs): Provide a variety of types of network access to the end systems.
    • Each ISP network, whether upper-tier or lower-tier, is managed independently, runs th IP protocol, and conforms to certain naming and address conventions.
  • Protocols: Control the sending and receiving of information within the Internet.
  • Transmission Control Protocol(TCP) and Internet Protocol(IP): Two of the most important protocols in the Internet.
    • IP: Specifies the format of the packets that are sent and received among routers and end systems.
    • TCP/IP: The Internet’s principal protocols.
  • Internet standards: A standard that everyone agree on what each and every protocol does.
  • Requests for comments(RFCs): Standards documents that the Internet Engineering Task Force(IETF) developed.
    • There are currently nearly 9000 RFCs that define protocols such as TCP, IP, HTTP(for the Web), and SMTP(for e-mail).

2️⃣ A Services Description

  • Distributed applications: Multiple end systems that exchange data with each other.
    • Internet applications run on end systems and NOT in packet switches in network core.
  • Socket interface: Set of rules that the sending program must follow so that the Internet can deliver the data to the destination program.
    • This is similar to the postal service, which you need to follow certain rules such as putting the stamp, having the sender’s and receiver’s postal code, address, and etc.

3️⃣ What is a Protocol?

Human Analogy

Computer network protocols are similar to how humans interact.

Network Protocols

Similar to human protocols, network protocols communicate through “wire” by controlling the flow of bits.

A protocol defines the format and the order of messages exchanged between two or more communicating entities, as well as the actions taken on the transmission and/or receipt of a message or other event.

Reference

  • Computer Networking 8th: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross
  • Computer Network Lecture by Seungsik Choi in Incheon National University
